text: Kia ora katoa, mauri ora kia tātou. So yeah, speaking to our kōrero report for obviously July through to September, you'll be aware that the previous kōrero saw the re-emergence of COVID-19 and this had big impacts on our area of business as it has with many people.  Our teams and facilities worked super well, shifting between the change in alert levels and the added challenges associated with working in levels 3 and 2. I'll briefly cover some of our key highlights that we were still able to achieve over the previous call despite those disruptions.  The first one, we managed to complete the John Hewitt Drive specimen tree planting in August. That was either side of that first lockdown period, thanks to Delta. These trees are going to provide a fantastic avenue for that popular park at Waipuki in the years to come. So we're really glad to get that across the line. As part of that, we also partnered with the Cambridge Tree Trust  who planted and mulched the majority of the triangle gardens along the driveway with native plants. And this will strengthen the ecological corridor between Maungatautere and the awa. And we're looking to partner with them again next year to finish off the triangles that weren't compared this season.  We're still getting a large amount of vandalism across our parks and public toilets. This has been really frustrating and, quite frankly, heartbreaking for both our staff and contractors working to make our open spaces beautiful, vibrant places. Some of you may have been contacted by frustrated residents in relation to some of this antisocial behaviour as well.  We do have a programme of work to improve the security of some of our hotspots, including guest light theatre and Pukemako. Some of the measures include adding security cameras, speed bumps and additional or renewed bollards and gating. Unfortunately, this programme of work has also been impacted by the COVID-19 delays and contract availability and also product supply issues.  The library teams have done a fantastic job working between the different alert levels. It seems that whenever we get an announcement by the government regarding the tightening alert levels, people flock to the libraries to stock up on books and get set for a long haul. And during the first week open at Alert Level 2 in September,  Cambridge Library issued just over 8,000 items alone and had over 4,500 items returned. So some really big numbers. I think actually that week in particular was a record ever for our libraries.  The Parks Operations team, they've worked with the Farmer's Market and the Cambridge Cricket Club to improve the turf health of Victoria Square. Ongoing management will continue with the Farmer's Market to ensure they use different areas of the square during the year to minimise or reduce the wear and tear in one particular spot.  Council, using its delegation, provided ministerial approval for the Maungatūturu Reserve Management Plan. And we've also commenced our project planning, including initial discussions with Ngāui Tōpua Waipā for three key pieces of work that we're doing in our team, looking at concept plans for  the district cemeteries, concept plans for the lakeside reserves, and also looking into our lease model review for sports parks we currently have across the district. So despite some of the challenges of last quarter, to provide you with a bit of a brief snapshot of what our team's been up to over that time,  which is commencing just a bit of a reminder, really. We've got Cambridge on Friday from 4.30 to 6 o'clock, and then also, you know, we've got a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of a bit of  a Saturday session, and that time escaped me. But we do have the two sessions coming up this week. We actually just had our first one on Te Atumutu this evening as well, and despite a decent share of heavy rain, had a reasonably good turnout with some good discussion. So that's proving very worthwhile.  Sorry, just one other thing I'll just add. Previously, last month, we came to you regarding the limited domain mural. There's an update on that that was approved at SPMP committee this week. So we'll be looking to kick that off, or we're running out of time a bit in December now, but at least into January to get that work going ahead. So I'm happy to take any questions that anyone has on our report or the update.
